Literature Review: Wood-boring pests (WBPs) represent a significant threat to forest ecosystems worldwide, causing extensive damage and economic losses. Early detection of WBP infestations is crucial for effective management and prevention of widespread forest destruction. Remote sensing technologies have emerged as powerful tools for monitoring and detecting WBP infestations at various scales and stages. This literature review aims to synthesize current research on the application of remote sensing techniques for early monitoring of forest wood-boring pests.Remote sensing offers numerous advantages for forest pest monitoring, including the ability to cover large areas efficiently, detect subtle changes in vegetation health, and provide frequent, non-invasive observations. Satellite-based remote sensing has been widely used for forest health assessment and pest detection. Wulder et al. (2006) demonstrated the potential of Landsat imagery for mapping mountain pine beetle infestations in British Columbia, Canada. Their study showed that multi-temporal Landsat data could detect changes in forest spectral properties associated with pest-induced tree mortality.While satellite imagery provides broad-scale coverage, the spatial resolution may be insufficient for detecting early-stage infestations. To address this limitation, researchers have explored the use of high-resolution airborne sensors. Fassnacht et al. (2014) utilized hyperspectral imagery from the Airborne Visible/Infrared Imaging Spectrometer (AVIRIS) to detect and map bark beetle-induced tree mortality in a mixed conifer forest. Their results indicated that hyperspectral data could distinguish between healthy and infested trees with high accuracy, even at early infestation stages.The advent of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) has revolutionized forest pest monitoring by providing a flexible and cost-effective platform for acquiring high-resolution imagery. Dash et al. (2017) demonstrated the effectiveness of UAV-based multispectral imaging for detecting emerald ash borer infestations in urban forests. Their study showed that UAV-derived vegetation indices could identify stressed ash trees with an accuracy of over 80%, outperforming traditional ground-based surveys.Thermal remote sensing has also shown promise for early detection of WBP infestations. Heurich et al. (2010) used airborne thermal imagery to detect bark beetle infestations in a temperate mountain forest. They found that infested trees exhibited higher canopy temperatures compared to healthy trees, allowing for early detection of pest activity before visible symptoms appeared.Advancements in machine learning and artificial intelligence have greatly enhanced the ability to analyze remote sensing data for pest detection. Senf et al. (2015) developed a random forest classifier to map bark beetle infestations using multi-temporal Landsat data. Their approach achieved high accuracy in distinguishing between healthy and infested forest stands, demonstrating the potential of machine learning algorithms for automated pest detection.LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) technology has emerged as a valuable tool for assessing forest structure and health. Shendryk et al. (2016) combined LiDAR and hyperspectral data to detect red attack stage mountain pine beetle infestations. Their integrated approach improved detection accuracy compared to using either data source alone, highlighting the benefits of multi-sensor fusion for pest monitoring.Despite the progress made in remote sensing-based pest detection, several challenges remain. One major limitation is the difficulty in detecting early-stage infestations before visible symptoms appear. To address this, researchers have explored the use of novel spectral indices and advanced statistical techniques. Kharuk et al. (2017) developed a modified normalized difference water index (MNDWI) to detect early-stage silk moth outbreaks in Siberian pine forests using Landsat data. Their approach showed promise for identifying infested areas before visible defoliation occurred.Another challenge is the need for frequent and timely observations to capture the dynamic nature of pest infestations. The integration of multiple remote sensing platforms and data sources can help overcome this limitation. Meddens et al. (2013) demonstrated the value of combining high-resolution aerial imagery with Landsat time series for mapping bark beetle-induced tree mortality across large areas. Their multi-scale approach provided both detailed spatial information and long-term temporal context for understanding infestation patterns.Looking to the future, emerging technologies such as hyperspectral satellite sensors and small satellite constellations offer new opportunities for forest pest monitoring. These advancements promise to provide higher spatial and temporal resolution data over large areas, potentially revolutionizing early detection capabilities. Additionally, the integration of remote sensing with other data sources, such as climate data and pest population models, could further enhance our ability to predict and manage WBP outbreaks.In conclusion, remote sensing technologies have demonstrated significant potential for early monitoring of forest wood-boring pests. The integration of multiple sensors, platforms, and analysis techniques offers a powerful approach for detecting and mapping pest infestations at various scales. However, continued research is needed to improve early detection capabilities, particularly for subtle changes associated with initial infestation stages. As remote sensing technologies continue to advance, they will play an increasingly important role in forest health monitoring and pest management strategies.
